channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for RI
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for RI

item.title: Report I-2023090154
item.description:
Report I-2023090154

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-17T15:12:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-13
  • City: Sunol
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CHEMICAL TRANSFER CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver got lost, drove onto a narrow rural road and could not negotiate a sharp tum causing left rear of trailer to leave road and rolled down an embankment. When the trailer overturned, it hit a small tree which had branches that entered the spill dam/ rollover protection area and hit the 3/4 inch air inlet line at the base of the Fort Valve PRD and broke the 3/4 inch stainless steel nipple for the air inlet line. There were no other package failures. At this point the cargo tank lost approximately 300 gallons, ER personnel would not allow us to stop the leak until there the tank was anchored by a recovery unit. We requested a tow truck to anchor it around 5:30 on Wed 9-13-2023, but one was never called. At approximately 7:00 PM, the incident commander decided to put off all efforts on hold until 7:30/8:00 AM the following morning due to location and darkness setting in. Due to no cell phone coverage in the area, we had requested ER personnel made all required ^ notifications to EPA, CaIOES, NRC, etc. California Highway Patrol was IC, Alameda Fire was on site, Ambulance, Fish and Wildlife, local environmental agency, the Sf Water district, etc were all onsite. At 07:30 on 9-14-23, a recovery 65 ton rotator arrived on site to secure the trailer. At approximately 8:30 we were allowed to do damage assessment on the trailer and found the source of the leak, drove a redwood plug onto it and stopped the leak. We then hooked up a 2 inch hose between the discharge line and a 70 barrel vacuum tank. By this time, since plugging was delayed, the cargo tank lost approximately 2,000 gallons of product. Tank was emptied, recovered and uprighted.
